close_symbols: type lfs_t (definition and fields: root, rcache, mlist, lfs1)
file/flag constants: LFS_F_DIRTY, LFS_F_INLINE, LFS_F_WRITING, LFS_TYPE_REG
explanation: To determine whether lfs_fs_traverse_ can lead to out-of-bounds accesses through <string.h> functions, the analyzer must inspect any callees (and their callees) that might perform memory operations (memcpy/memmove/memset/etc.) on buffers or blocks referenced/passed by lfs_fs_traverse_. The listed functions are the direct callees and their transitive callees shown in the static call graph that are most likely to manipulate directory/ctz buffers or read block data (e.g. lfs_dir_fetch, lfs_dir_get, lfs_ctz_traverse, lfs_bd_read and their helpers). The listed struct/type definitions (struct lfs_ctz, struct lfs_mdir_t, struct lfs_file_t, lfs_t and lfs_stag_t) and macros/constants (LFS_MKTAG, lfs_tag_type3, LFS_TYPE_*, LFS_ERR_*, LFS_BLOCK_NULL, LFS_MIGRATE, flag constants) are required because they define buffer layout, sizes, tag encodings and control flow (when alternate traversal like lfs1_traverse runs, or when file ctz/cache/inline conditions change). Without these symbol definitions and the implementations of the listed functions you cannot determine the sizes and provenance of destination/source buffers or whether any memcpy/memmove/memset/etc. in the call chain can access beyond object bounds. Each listed symbol either: (a) may itself call string.h functions or memory-copying code that operates on buffers passed from lfs_fs_traverse_, or (b) defines the structures, sizes, flags or macros that determine the lengths and bounds of those buffers and thus are necessary to reason about safe/unsafe memory accesses.
